Hi Ken, 

I just uploaded it. You will see some non-oscillating behaviors a=
long 
the way, but it is OK as these are novel early in evolution and later=
 
genetic defects lead to stabilizing substrates sometimes. 

I hope you wi=
ll enjoy it too. :) 

Let me answer your questions. Yes, I do mean that the=
 individuals 
stay in the mid-air, but their behavior is no longer distance=
 
travelled or arrival point, but the internal oscillation behavior of 
the=
 output nodes. Actually the values in the behavior 
characterization's vect=
or are a measure of the frequency of 
oscillations. There are restriction t=
o this, too, because the 
substrate's nodes can have a time constant range =
of (2.5 .. 5) and 
the timestep of simulation is a kind of normal one consi=
dering there 
are 8 seconds for an individual's lifetime. So cases of just =
quickly 
blinking the activations should not appear. At least not frequentl=
y. 

I think these behaviors (like walking or swimming) are a good 
steppin=
g stone for further evolution (perhaps fitness search with an 
explicit obj=
ective). Once the general pattern of a walking or 
swimming behavior has be=
en discovered, this itself is a good stepping 
stone for the harder task (N=
S) or a fitness search. Though I am not 
planning to do such an experiment =
yet. 

Thanks for your kind yours :) 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Peter,
> 
> That is a fascinati=
ng experiment with the zero-gravity novelty 
search.
>  Would you consider =
uploading it so we can see the walkers and
> swimmers evolve?
> 
> One ques=
tion I have is when you say you get walkers "100% of the
> time," you mean =
they look like that are walking, but they are not
> actually walking right?=
  That is, these "walkers" are really just
> floating in mid-air, and if yo=
u actually placed them on the ground
> with gravity, they would probably no=
t balance?  Similarly, the
> swimmers may or may not swim in the friction o=
f water?  In other 
words
> you are discovering the aesthetic look of vario=
us activities but not
> necessarily the mechanical nuances?
> 
> Assuming I=
 am understanding that correctly, there is still a puzzle 
to
> get them to=
 go straight to walking on hard ground through novelty
> search.   But I th=
ink you're oscillation-detection novelty
> characterization is quite clever=
 and is progress in that direction.
> Very interesting work overall! 
> 
> =
ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@=
>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Jeff, 
> > 
> > I am glad that you like my program an=
d enjoy it! :) 
> > 
> > I know it would be cool to browse the archive, or =
have an 
external 
> > routine that queries the archive by different criter=
ia to show me 
> > what was achieved during the run, but this program now i=
s 
actually a 
> > stepping stone for another research project I have, evol=
ving 
leaky-
> > integrator substrates by HyperNEAT combined with evolving =
the 
> > substrate itself, all used in one Alife simulation of mass-spring =

> > creatures, sensing collision and reacting by contracting the 
springs.=
 
> > And all this with Novelty Search searching for new and new 
behaviors=
. 
> > I believe that this is a pretty serious test of how far 
complexity =

> > can go in such open-ended domain. I can later mix it with fitness 
> >=
 search once a good population has evolved, on objectives 
> > like "swimmi=
ng". 
> > 
> > Let me mention about one interesting experiment I made with =
the 
NS 
> > NEVH. I restricted the substrate connectivity so that output-
=
>output 
> > connections are not queried. Then I made the environment to 0 =

gravity 
> > and removed the ground plane. The behavior characterization w=
as 
> > changed like this. The behavior data is a vector of 15 doubles 
> >=
 representing the outputs. Each time an output oscillates (going 
to 
> > +=
treshold and then -treshold, or vice versa), its corresponding 
place 
> > =
in the vector is incremented. 
> > So the vector is actually counting how m=
any oscillations the 
outputs 
> > did during the lifetime. A substrate osc=
illating with high 
frequency 
> > is very far in the behavior space. Diffe=
rent outputs oscillating 
are 
> > counted too. The behavior distance metri=
c is the eucledian 
distance 
> > between these 15-D vectors. 
> > 
> > So =
novelty search now has to find new ways to oscillate the 
entire 
> > body,=
 to do repeating movements. In all the runs, Novelty Search 
with 
> > Hype=
rNEAT finds walking gaits 100% of the time, in the first 1000 
> > evaluati=
ons. There are also swimming gaits and all kind of stuff 
(I 
> > saw one i=
ndividual actually dancing :)) 
> > 
> > So what was stopping it from walki=
ng before, is the gravity. 
Keeping 
> > balance on one leg and trying to w=
alk at the same time turns out 
to 
> > be very hard task. One environmenta=
l constraint that would be 
useful 
> > to make it walk is, when only one f=
oot has stepped on the ground, 
> > stick that foot to the ground. So the c=
hance the humanoid to fall 
is 
> > minimized. 
> > 
> > As for the novelty=
 search stagnation, where getting new behaviors 
> > becomes hard, the popu=
lation begins to do something like a random 
> > probing anything that is n=
ot the same stuff. Then it begins to 
rely 
> > entirely on mutation to get=
 out somehow. 
> > 
> > Peter
> >

une <jclune@> wrote:

shuffle

gh I have seen a few three mini-step forward

n you post either the genome and or a movie of the best org

n so

browse the 
archive,

ers to view based on max 
distance 
> > from 0,0
> > > or something like th=
at.

viewing

oordinate in the

> > > color) and in the current populati=
on (another color).
> > > 
> > > Watching this also makes me wonder about t=
he population losing 
its 
> > gradient
> > > and disengaging. Here is the =
potential concern (and I think 
mattias 
> > and ken
> > > discussed this a=
lready): Once all the easy to access points are 
> > found, if
> > > most o=
f the orgs are not getting somewhere new, they will all 
have 
> > equal
> =
> > fitnesses and the search will not be focused on the outside 
edge. 
> >=
 Do you
> > > think this is happening (and might this be why David mentione=
d 
that 
> > he saw a
> > > lot of repeats toward the end)? The visualizati=
on I just 
proposed 
> > might help
> > > on this front. Do the points adde=
d in the archive tend to be 
> > further and
> > > further away from 0,0...=
.or is it just filling in the spaces in 
the 
> > nearby
> > > vicinity? 
>=
 > > 
> > > Despite these concerns/suggestions, it is very fun stuff to 
lo=
ok 
> > at...and
> > > its exciting that you are hybridizing these ideas so=
 quickly 
and 
> > testing
> > > them. 
> > >

> > > Cheers,

eff Clune

ined.  I ran

irs knees seemed pretty common).  No one that I saw

 plane?  I used your older version when it was first released,

 I
